title: Desktop Support Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Houston, TX) in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions:
The position was posted in a third-party job site on a Monday. I applied the same day and got a call back on Thursday. We have the phone interview next Monday and it went pretty well. He says that he will be flying in to town and would like to meet with me on Wednesday. 

I arrive on time, and did the interview with him and another of his colleague. The interview went for about 30-40 minutes. In the end, they mentioned that they will need the position to be filled as soon as possible and will let me know of their decision most likely by Friday. 

I do not hear back from them till Monday and decided to call the interviewer. He picks up and I remind him of who I was and an update of the job position. He then remembers who I was and ask if he can call me back real quick. Since I just called him out of the blue, I figured he must be in the middle of something. So I agree and disconnect the call. That was the last time I heard from him.

What I believe happened was that they had picked another person for the position and forgot to inform me. Which is a bit insulting considering that he just came to town so he mustn't have had a whole bunch of applicants to interview.  After not receiving his call in over an hour, I really thought I would get one of those "Thank you for applying" emails, but I guess he thought: "why should I have to call him to give him bad news? I'm sure that in a couple of hours after he doesn't receive my call, he will get the message."
Interview Questions: Tell us about yourself?

title: Enrollment Processor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (North Hollywood, CA) in Oct 2016
Interview Descriptions:
First, I had a phone screening with HR. She asked basic questions and said I would hear from the supervisor if they were interested. 

2 weeks later I received a phone call to set up the in-person interview. 
I was interviewed for 2 1/2 hours. 
First I met with the supervisor, who spoke at length about how much harder this job was than my old job (with no basis in reality) and asked a lot of questions without letting me answer them. She interrupted every time I tried to tell an anecdote illustrating my competence to talk about how this job was harder. I was warned no fewer than 10 times that the previous person in this position was amazing and I would never live up to her standard. 
Then, I met with a part time person. I am not sure why a part time coworker is involved in the interview process, but she was the friendliest and most professional of the bunch. She then admitted that the company is falling apart.
After a long wait, I then met with a manager. He spent a lot of time discussing other concerns with the supervisor in front of me, and then revealed that the supervisor was going on leave soon and the PT person was leaving her role, so it was "sink or swim." I described similar circumstances I had survived before and let them know I could handle it. He asked me the same questions I had already gone over at length with the previous two interviewers and again did not really let me answer. I asked about compensation and neither of them had any idea.
Finally, after 2 1/2 hours, I was told that I would "definitely" hear from them by the next day (Friday). It is now a week later and I have not even heard the customary "we went with someone else." Very unprofessional, and a huge waste of my time.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with conflict in the workplace?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Nashville, TN)
Interview Descriptions:
Sent in my application through their online site, received an email within 2 days to set up an interview for the next week. I came through a referral so they were very excited to meet me. 

When I first got in they required that I fill out a full paper application, even though all of the information they were requesting was already submitted electronically. This was my first red flag, why waste 20 minutes of my time - so that I was then late to my interview - to fill out a paper application when one is already available to the company? The interview was based on this paper application and you could tell the application and resume was glanced over for a few seconds at most and they conducted the interview accordingly. If you invite someone in for an interview you would think they would have reviewed your resume for at least a couple minutes to get a slight feel of the person.

They were not interested in anything but sales experience, even with a thorough background in education. No commission, but it is 100% a sales job. They described it as "only" 4 hours of cold calling a day, with other administrative tasks the rest of the day. Interview was less than 30 minutes with a tour around the building afterwards. Building was small and it made me uneasy that they were convincing mostly low-income students to pay $100k+ to attend an arts school. They were definitely looking for people who were hungry for the job, and I took the interview as a courtesy to my referrer, not because I truly wanted the position. I did not get the position, and found out through a letter at the end of the week. The entire process seemed dated, I didn't realize company's still sent rejection letters.
Interview Questions: Questions were usual interview questions, kept asking if I had any sales experience.

title: Receptionist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (San Francisco, CA) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions: I received an email for an "information session" regarding this position. I found that strange but attended regardless. When I arrived, there were about 15 people in the reception area filing out applications for this position. Um...didn't I already Fill out an application when I input all of my Information online?!?!!? I felt as if I were completing an application for a temporary agency for placement. After the application was completed, we were herded into a classroom and told about the position. I guess this weeds out those interested and those who are not, but I think the worst thing is seeing your "competition" versus assuming the unseen competition. The information session was pretty straightforward. The person who the Receptionist will be working with discussed the role further and I didn't see this is a good fit for me due to work schedule, the Supervisor's wants, and how he kept talking about this is "a business." I understand the business model but this view of indicating that this institute views this as "a business" was completely off-putting. There wasn't anything particularly inviting about this information session. After this was over, we were herded back downstairs and interviewed one on one. What I couldn't understand is how this felt like a cattle call. The supervisor and office manager who interviewed everyone one by one didn't even have any particular questions specific and/or tailored to me. He simply regurgitated my resume back to me with superficial questions that weren't even difficult. I couldn't understand how they would get a candidate of high caliber that way. I wasn't even challenged! I was floored by the whole experience. And completely unimpressed.
Interview Questions: There weren't any difficult questions because they were asking questions on the fly with no preparation whatsoever.

title: Recruiter Interview

Interview Descriptions: I had 2 interviews for the Recruiter position - one was more like a group info session, and then if you were still interested you could wait for your own 10 minute interview. This went well, and I received a callback interview. The second interview was a panel interview with 3 managers. This also went well, though it was becoming obvious to all of us that it wasn't a good fit for me. The very next day I received a call from the dept manager wanting me to consider an alternate position. I shadowed someone for about an hour, then we had another private interview. Ultimately, they offered me the position, which I turned down. I will say that I enjoyed every person I talked with and met. It seems like a great company with really great people. Even though I didn't take the position, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this company.
Interview Questions: I don't remember any specific questions. There were lots of situation type questions and "tell us of a time" questions. Go in with lots of stories to choose from.

title: Media Arts Instructor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Sunnyvale, CA) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Great.  Brief.  Had one phone interview and an on-site demo for a small team of instructors.  The director was very informative and answered all of my questions.  I got a tour of the facility and met a few of the team instructors that I would work closest with.
Interview Questions: What makes your teaching style significant?  How do you reach students from diverse backgrounds?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Tucson, AZ) in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions:
I had to go in at least 3 times before getting an offer. First day was a group interview where we all sat around a table and they contacted me back after that one.
Then the second time in it broke into more individual with the director and HR, doing role play and full on interview. One of the only times I can remember doing role playing in an interview! It was at least an hour long, and I was contacted by HR a few days after with a formal offer.
Interview Questions: We are going to do a role play where I will pretend to be a student, are you ready?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Houston, TX)
Interview Descriptions: I received a call about a week later after I applied for the position. I had one interview and I was hired. It's very easy to get hired here.
Interview Questions: None.  I was asked "why" I wanted the position. Overall, it was a very "to the point" interview process.

title: Adjunct Faculty Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process consisted of a phone screen to start.  The next step was a personal interview.  In the final step I had to prepare and present a classroom lecture.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to teach?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview

Called 2 days after with Director of Admissions, few minutes later call from Senior Director of Admissions, giving basic info about job.
Went two days later met Senior Director, and had interview with the other Director of Admissions.
One week later  HR called with job offer.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Milwaukee, WI) in Nov 2012
Interview Descriptions:

2nd= Met with Director of Admissions.  Again, very flashy... and more of the focus on on her and her life story.  Very weird.
3rd= Met with the President of the Campus.  Again, just weird.  Non-job related questions and more of a life story/talking to fill quiet air.  I found myself fishing for answers to try to get to the bottom of what it was that I would REALLY be doing in the position.

title: Admission Director Assistant Interview

Describe in detail your daily routine at your last job. 
Why do you want to work in education?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Chicago, IL) in Oct 2012
Interview Descriptions: Two interviews, one with a director of admissions and another with the president of the school. Both are intelligent and nice people. Just be yourself and you will have a good conversation at the very least.
Interview Questions: Why did I want a job that required mostly all phone-oriented work?

title: Residence Life Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Schaumburg, IL) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was real easy. Met with HR, Director of Housing, and Dean of Student Affairs. Typical interview questions. All were lovely people. I really enjoyed meeting the group and got excited to start with the position. The Dean, who is now retired, was the greatest. The Director of Housing and I got along really well and instantly had chemistry to make the department very successful.
Interview Questions: Why are you qualified for this position?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions/Academic Recruiter Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Fort Worth, TX) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and the following day I received an email response to see If I would accept a group session. After confirming, In the information session we were to go over the institution and its background, go over the position requirements, and the expectations, along with salary details which was fairly good/average in the low to mid 40's. The information session was with the Senior Director and Director of Admissions. Afterwards we were to do one on one interviews which never happened I've never experienced anything like this along with a group of 9 other candidates. It was pretty unprofessional all we were allowed to do was go around the table and sell ourselves short why we would be the best candidate. After that we all left and the following morning I received a survey once completed about minutes later another email for a background check. To my knowledge a background check I figured meant i was in however not on their terms it was a screening process. Who pays money to do a background check and then don't give you the chance to have a proper interview. Needless to say even though my background is good I received almost a week later I wasn't selected for whatever reason.
Interview Questions: Explain how you would be the best person for this position?

title: Full Time Faculty Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Atlanta, GA)
Interview Descriptions: I was flown in from another town, interviewed by a group of faculty members.
Interview Questions: How to handle conflict.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Phoenix, AZ) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions: First steps are an over the phone interview, then a face to face interview, then you are tested on how well you can hold a conversation with one of the directors. Be enthusiastic and engaged and be prepared to ask questions.
Interview Questions: The over the phone conversation test was difficult. It was hard to understand the expectations initially.

title: Teacher Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (San Bernardino, CA) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions: Very easy interview because the director was easy going . Too bad that they could not keep him, we loved him. The position was for an outgoing instructor who is a friend of mine so I can recommended. that may have made the process easier. I had a presentation to make to the other directors which was not that hard. They wanted to see my teaching style. I don't regret for one minute my experience at the Art Institutes its when they REALLY started to focus on money that the whole place started to go downhill.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Seattle, WA) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions: There is a group interview and if they deem you worthy they follow up with an individual interview. After that if they are still interested they will schedule you for another interview. In my case I was told they were running my background and reference checks (which took three weeks). I was under the impression I was going to be hired, all of my references were great. Then at the last minute they called to say they were going a different direction. My advice would be don't slow down on your job search to wait for this company! Also from everything I've gathered, employee moral especially for ADA's was very low. My best advise would be to steer clear all together.
Interview Questions: Asked about a former supervisor who you liked the management style of, and one that you didn't.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview

Interview Descriptions: Very basic interview... nothing too specific... seems like they will hire most people who can speak well, and aren't on drugs.
Interview Questions: How will you stay motivated since we can't pay commission?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 months. I interviewed at The Art Institutes in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: Instead of interviewing initially, you do an 'Information Session' about the role with a group of people. They aren't really in any hurry to call you back. It took a month when I heard back, then I went through 3 interviews with different directors, 6 mos later got the offer.
Interview Questions: They asked me what are "deal breakers" for me with a company or manager.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Tinley Park, IL) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions:
The first point of contact was from an HR rep that phone screened candidates. After, I received and email inviting me to a group information session. Upon arriving for the information session, along with 10 other people, there were clip boards handed out and applications to be completed. We were then shuffled into a small classroom where a presentation was given by the Director of Admission for that campus. The presentation consisted of information about the company in general, then went in depth about the positions and expectations of candidates. Lastly, the HR benefits were talked about, where it seemed more like they were selling us on the job, rather then have us sell them.

They reps from the school then asked if anyone would like to leave now, if they feel the position isn't right for them. I knew this wasn't the job for me after the presentation as I didn't want to be in a sales position, but I stayed for the remainder of the interview. They then informed us that each of us would be taken one by one and asked a few more questions, a quick personal interview. So, they took each of us, one. by. one. It took two hours to get through everyone, and they went in a random order, not by arrival time.

The process was a bit ridiculous for the position, and came across like selling insurance. Hard to sell a $70,000 plus education from a private company to a student who deserves better.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to be in a sales job?

title: Faculty Member Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Atlanta, GA) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview was mostly behavioral questions. They wanted to know things like how I handled difficult situations and how well I worked under pressure. I met with the Depatment director first and then there was a committee interview about a week later. It was a very pleasant group. They were sincerely interested in my background. I had to do a teaching presentation for the committee. This school goes year round, so there are no Summers off.
Interview Questions: Name a time you had a conflict with a co-worker; how did you solve it?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Santa Monica, CA) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview with recruiter. Then a group interview with other candidates. At the end of the group interview you will meet individually with the director who will ask you a few questions. If you make it to the next round you will meet with the senior director, HR and at least one director for a final interview. The key is to be animated and talkative. You may not receive an answer that day but a next day offer is expected.
Interview Questions: Pretty typical sales questions. How do you stay motivated when doing a task over and over again? (You make a lot of dials on the phone.)

title: Adjunct Faculty Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Saint Louis, MO) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: Initial review involved group "interview," where about 15 potential candidates were given an introductory speech and tour of the company. We introduced ourselves and filled out standard application paperwork, which was turned in with our printed resumes. Many candidates did not have traditional faculty backgrounds (lots of MATs or business professionals, very few MAs and MFAs). We then set up individual interview times. For the individual interviews, we gave a class presentation to the Dean and met briefly to discuss the position. Only continue if you know this is an entry-level, resume building job that will enable you to move on to something else. There is virtually no room to advance within the company.
Interview Questions: "Is the pay rate typical for the area?"

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Santa Monica, CA) in Mar 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by a recruiter. First, had a group info session where they discussed what the position would entail.  It was a very thorough presentation and quite comprehensive.  There were six candidates in the room and it seemed crucial to ask questions and to stand out. Following, there was a one on one interview that lasted approximately five minutes.  Received a call back a day later. Went back to be interviewed by the two directors and the executive director. I received news the same day by the recruiter that they wanted to make an offer. Less than a week later, HR contacted me with the salary offer and was informs there would be a background check.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with rejection?

This includes both in-bound and out-bound calling, face-to-face student meetings and variable hours that consist of days, evenings and some Saturdays.
Interview Questions: Why I wanted to work for The Art Institute.

title: Printing Technician Interview

Interview Descriptions: Very easy and quick process, this should have been a red flag but I needed a change fast so I went with it. I wish I would have been able to meet the management team beforehand as I would have declined the offer or asked for much more money.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you dealt with a tough situation

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Saint Louis, MO) in Jan 2012

The job description made it sound as if we were going to help people and run our own business, however, we are micro managed and feeding students lies.

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Tucson, AZ) in Mar 2011
Interview Descriptions:
The company is very upfront that the interview process could take 2 - 3 months. Interview started with a presentation of answers to frequently asked questions. Then we were given a tour from one of the "Assistant Directors." This title implies management, but it is just a sales position. The actual assistant director is called the associate director. The position is about 6-8 hours of calling combined with 2 hours or so of giving interested students tours of the facility and then signing them up for the next step. After the tour we went to a 15-20 minute interview.

The people seemed professional and kind. The interview was standard. Why this job? What are your strengths? Were you ever frustrated with not making a sale and what did you do? The interviewer was concerned that I had other Saturday obligations for a couple of months and stated that this was a problem. This company wants you to eat, sleep, and breath sales for them without scheduling conflicts.

This is an hourly position that depends on mandatory overtime to make the stated salary of $30-$35,000. With the time and half and the hours expected 55-60 this puts the hourly wage at around $10 per hour. It seemed that the management was looking for people that were "hungry" for a job, and willing to wait a long time to get it. The other applicants interviewing with me were also put off by the long term interview process. We all had interviews with other companies the following week. This seems like a good way to  lose top talented personnel.
Interview Questions: Have you ever lost a sale and what did you do about it?

After spending several hours there I never heard back from anyone.  No rejection nothing.  That is really not the way to do business.  It was very unprofessional.
Interview Questions: Tell me why you should get this job.

Interview Questions: Tell me more about yourself

title: Career Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (North Hollywood, CA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions:
I first did a phone interview (screening) with a company recruiter (HR).  They asked some basic questions - why applying, name weaknesses & strengths, describe previous experience.

First Interview: I met with the Director of Career Services 1:1 interview.  Pleasant interview, she asked basic expected interview questions, plus a couple of hard ones.

Second Interview:  I met with one of the Career Advisors.  Pleasant interview, questions were geared more for company fit than experience.

- After these two I felt that I was going to get an offer.

Third Interview:  Met with Director of HR. Totally not necessary , but could tell that he just wanted to be part of the decision making process.  I think this is where I lost the offer - but good for me, cause I got another job offer that was better suited for me later on!

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Draper, UT) in Mar 2010
Interview Descriptions: They start by inviting a large group of people to come to the campus and learn more about the position.  It's a great forum to ask questions and potentially sticking out.  From there they invite you to meet one on one if you're still interested.  After the one on one interview they will call you back to set up another round of one on one's.  I interviewed with the Senior Director of Admissions and HR Rep as well as the campus President and CFO.  All were very professional and well spoken... the CFO had no clue what he was doing and really didn't know much about my position, but other than that, it's important to impress everyone.  In my opinion the trait they're looking for is that you are comfortable talking with people and are able to gather information from the conversation.  Being able to ask open ended questions is a great strategy.  I recommended a friend and told him to mention "open ended questions" in his interview and he got the job.
Interview Questions: (in regards to potential student) How would you get someone to talk to you if they were very shy?

title: High School Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Chicago, IL) in Mar 2010
Interview Descriptions: An employee forwarded my resume and cover letter to the hiring manager. I was then contacted via email and asked to complete a questionnaire. The manager liked my answers and I received and email a couple of days later inviting me to a group information session where I learned more about the role as well as the compensation (benefits and salary parameters) that the position offered. It was conducted by two individuals, who stated the hiring decision was a group one. I was also asked in the email to prepare a 2-3 minute presentation on the benefits of a product or service, as this is an educational sales job. A couple of days after delivering my speech, I received a call to set up a phone interview. I was provided with a phone number and access code to dial in. There were three people on the line, the two who had conducted the group session and one additional person who did not say anything. The interview was a little tricky, but the interviewers were friendly. I was told I would be contacted by either way. Two weeks later, I was notified that they went with someone else for the position. The company culture seems great- they really want to see their employees grow within the company, the benefits package outstanding, and the hiring manager was extremely down-to-earth. The presentation rattled my nerves a bit, so I suggest preparing well in advice. Further, when asked to "tell me about yourself" I advise prospective candidates to really focus on their sales experience, whatever that might me. A little bummed I was not offered the position, but the interview series was great experience of what to, and not to, do on a sales interview.
Interview Questions: Tell me more about yourself, beyond what we see here on your resume.

Interview Questions: ...the strengths and weaknesses question always gets me.

title: Student Worker Mail Clerk Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Philadelphia, PA) in Jan 2010
Interview Descriptions: Show interest and persistence. That'll help you land the job. Become acquainted with those in charge of the position and visit from time to time to see if there will be available positions. Just remember that you will most likely be replacing a student currently working there, so becoming acquainted with them might be somewhat awkward once they discover they've been cut and replaced by you. Still, it doesn't hurt to reach out to the student workers either. They may be the ones to help you get your foot in the door.
Interview Questions: Are you still interested in the position?

title: Assistant Director of Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Pittsburgh, PA) in Jul 2009
Interview Descriptions: You are induced (an illegal action considering the realities that unfold later) by lies that the job is about interviewing students and helping them achieve a dream of starting college. Within a week or so of training, it becomes abundantly clear that it is a hard-sales job. The company is always hiring for this job because it is always firing these employees. No staffer can always make the unrealistic quotas (thinly disguised as "goals") imposed, but these quotas and how they are used to illegally fire you (constructive dismissal) are not explained in the interview process.
Interview Questions: What would you do to save a student who applied and is wanting to cancel?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at The Art Institutes (Minneapolis, MN) in May 2008
Interview Descriptions: Started with a cover letter and resume, followed by three interviews and a presentation.  Employees seemed to enjoy their work environment.  My first interview was a group interview with the Vice President and two other program directors for the school.  The second interview was a one on one with the President who then sent me to a one on one with the head of human resources.  I was called by a few weeks later to do a demonstration lesson in front of a class with a group review from the Vice President, President and two other program directors.
Interview Questions: What is my favorite color?
